title: 109_s1869
content: The Act titled "Coastal Barrier Resources Reauthorization Act of 2005" defines key terms like "otherwise protected area," "pilot project," "Secretary," and "System unit." It also mentions the digital mapping pilot project authorized under a previous Act. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 2 years regarding digital maps of System units and protected areas created under a pilot project. The report must be prepared in consultation with Governors, allow for public comments, and include final recommended digital maps. The final report to Congress will include recommended digital maps from the pilot project, adoption recommendations, summaries of comments received, updates on protocols and findings, and an analysis of benefits from digital mapping technology. $500,000 is authorized for each fiscal year 2006 through 2007 for this purpose. DIGITAL MAPPING PROJECT for the remaining John H. Chafee Coastal Barrier Resources System units and protected areas. The Secretary will create digital versions of all John H. Chafee Coastal Barrier Resources System maps, including maps of protected areas not covered in the pilot project. Existing spatial data from Federal, State, and local agencies will be used, and other agencies must provide data upon request at no cost. The Secretary will create digital versions of all John H. Chafee Coastal Barrier Resources System maps, using existing spatial data from Federal, State, and local agencies. Non-Federal entities are encouraged to provide data to the Secretary at no cost. If necessary data is missing, an agreement will be made for the United States Geological Survey to obtain and provide the required data. The Secretary will create digital maps of the John H. Chafee Coastal Barrier Resources System using data that complies with national standards. A report on these maps will be submitted to the Senate and House committees within 5 years. The report required under paragraph (1) shall include a description of boundary line differences on digital maps, a summary of comments received, and recommendations for Congress adoption. The report to Congress will include recommendations for expanding protected areas, updates on digital map implementation, and funding requirements for making maps available digitally and integrating boundaries into planning tools. Authorization of $1,000,000 is provided for this purpose. The Secretary is authorized $1,000,000 annually from 2006 to 2010 for carrying out this section. SEC. 5. Authorization of appropriations amended to cover the years 2006 through 2010.
